500 connections, 1600 followers


About
Dan has spent more than 30 years in the retail and service industries. Specializing in marketing & business development, inventory planning, operations and customer driven sales management. He is an award-winning business coach with a proven understanding of what it takes to be successful as an entrepreneur. Dan spent 16 years in senior management and ownership roles with multi-store retailers before joining Canadian Retail Solutions as their CEO, Director of Retail Planning. Dan works directly with clients’ coast to coast representing hundreds of retail categories. He is the founder of The Wealthy Retailer™ which began as an educational series delivering a successive in-depth look at key areas for growing and nurturing retail stores to maximize their profit potential.

## Posts
**Retail Council of Canada** (1d): The Canadian retail sector employed 2.3 million people - essentially flat month over month but continuing the gains seen since the first quarter of 2025. Part-time employment fell 5% from June and has been on a steady decline since May, likely tied to the nationwide closure of Hudson’s Bay. Youth employment remains a concern, with fewer temporary positions available between May and August than in previous years. 💡 For full insights and updated data, check out RCC's Member-only Retail Pulse Dashboard. https://hubs.ly/Q03D8zJJ0 [Likes: 4, Comments: 0]; **Retail Council of Canada** (1d Edited): 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗱𝗲 𝗨𝗽𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗲: 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗦𝗲𝗽𝘁. 𝟭, 𝟮𝟬𝟮𝟱, 𝗖𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗱𝗮 𝘄𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝗿𝗲𝗺𝗼𝘃𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿-𝘁𝗮𝗿𝗶𝗳𝗳𝘀 𝗼𝗻 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗖𝗨𝗦𝗠𝗔 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗮𝗻𝘁 𝗨.𝗦. 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲𝗿 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱𝘀, while tariffs remain in place on steel, aluminum, and autos. RCC welcomes this step as a move toward easing costs for consumers and retailers, and we hope it paves the way for a more stable and predictable trade relationship with the U.S. Going forward, clarity will be essential, as the changes also introduce added complexity and administrative burden for retailers. 𝗥𝗖𝗖 𝗶𝘀 𝗮𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗹𝘆 𝗲𝗻𝗴𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗼𝗳𝗳𝗶𝗰𝗶𝗮𝗹𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘄𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝘀𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝘁𝗮𝗶𝗹𝘀 𝗮𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝘆 𝗯𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗮𝘃𝗮𝗶𝗹𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲. #cdnpoli #Retail #RetailMatters #TariffImpact #CanadaUSTrade https://lnkd.in/gZJsewv3 [Likes: 2, Comments: 0]; **Retail Council of Canada** (1d): Catch up on this week's retail news, including the duty-free crisis, Target changing its leadership, and more! https://hubs.ly/Q03DXcCw0 Get it all on Friday mornings with the #RetailThisWeek newsletter. Sign up here: https://hubs.ly/Q03DXhBL0 [Likes: 1, Comments: 0]; **Retail Council of Canada** (2d): 🚀 London Drugs is proving that retail jobs can launch lasting careers. At #RCCRetailWest , Hermanjit Mahil, P.Log will share how this Western Canadian retailer is redefining career growth by fostering advancement from within. 🌟 From in-store beginnings to head office leadership, hear team member career stories and learn how London Drugs’ robust programs empower frontline staff to explore corporate pathways—turning frontline jobs into dynamic, long-term careers. ⏳ Early Bird rates end NEXT WEEK - August 28! https://retailwest.ca/ #WesternCanada #Retail #RetailCareers #TalentDevelopment [Likes: 7, Comments: 0]; **Retail Council of Canada** (3d): Exclusive Opportunity for Vendors & Suppliers! Join us for a special Breakfast Event with Gino Dorico, Senior Vice President & Country Manager, Costco Wholesale Canada . 📅 September 16, 2025 📍 Toronto Airport Marriott Hotel With 37 years of experience at Costco, Gino Dorico has led across multiple areas of the business and currently oversees 110 locations nationwide. This is a great chance to connect directly with Costco’s Canadian leadership and gain insights into the company’s priorities and growth strategy. 👉 Save the date and secure your spot early! https://lnkd.in/gChkMeBP [Likes: 22, Comments: 0]; **Retail Council of Canada** (4d): Breakfast with the President & CEO of Walmart Canada! She’ll be discussing a variety of key issues and trends in retail, from people-led strategy to the future of technology in retail. This is your chance to hear directly from one of Canada’s biggest retailers to better inform your 2025 holiday plans. Grab your tickets! results.title: Gary Hayes - Owner, Retail Adventure Inc.
results.content:
Gary Hayes
Owner, Retail Adventure Inc.
Pointe-Claire, Quebec, Canada
500 connections, 18052 followers


About
With a rich background in Canadian retailing, I have been at the forefront of innovative concepts that have left a lasting mark on the industry. One of my notable achievements was pioneering the BAYMART discount store concept at The Bay, long before the advent of Walmart in Canada. The success of BAYMART led to an expanded role, where I steered The Bay's foray into apparel, positioning it as a fashion leader in the 70's. Transitioning from department stores to specialty retail, I took on roles of increasing responsibility at Reitman's. As Vice President of Smart Set, and later as VP of Reitman's in the 80's, I introduced the groundbreaking in-season "item" repeat concept, a strategy that anticipated the "fast fashion" approach adopted by industry giants like Forever 21, H&M, and Zara. My journey then led me to Giant Tiger, where I devised and executed a robust fashion apparel strategy, fortifying GT against the challenges posed by Walmart. The events I orchestrated, including the PJ Party, Breast Cancer, Get Fit, Garden Party, and Canada Day celebrations, commanded a dominant presence in the market. I leverage my extensive experience in department stores, specialty retail, and discount stores to navigate the dynamic landscape of digital marketing. I know what has to be done on social media. My focus lies in evaluating retail strategies and uncovering emerging opportunities, all of which are meticulously documented in my weekly reports. THE REPORT: At the heart of my work is a weekly senior management report, meticulously crafted to unveil potential opportunities and highlight potential pitfalls. Armed with unfiltered information, this report empowers decision-makers to pose the right questions and allocate resources strategically to address the most pressing challenges.


Experience
Owner
[Retail Adventure Inc.](N/A)  
Jun 1999 - Present
Montreal, Quebec, Canada



Education
University of Oregon
Bachelor of Business Administration (B.B.A.), Marketing/Marketing Management, General
1959 - 1963

results.title: Zoran Kocovski - Founding Partner, Sassafraz Restaurant
results.content:
Zoran Kocovski
Founding Partner, Sassafraz Restaurant
Toronto, Ontario, Canada
500 connections, 724 followers


About
My roots run deep in the food world, and I wouldn’t want it any other way. I come from a Macedonian family entrenched in simple farming. When our family immigrated to Canada with few materials to our name, I was only an infant. My father took a position as a cook, and my mother as a factory worker, before they saved enough money to open a 50-seat diner in Toronto. The entrepreneurial spirit I witnessed in my dad had been in our family for generations. The value he put on an honest day’s work inspired me... It continues to motivate me today. With education being integral to my family, I went on to York University. Several business ventures later, I found myself back in the restaurant business with the launch of Sassafraz. When a devastating fire occurred there, it redefined my career as I came away with a new sense of the vital importance of community and a passion for creating positive change.


Experience
Principal
[Sassafraz Restaurant](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/sassafraz)  
Jul 1997 - Present
100 Cumberland Street



Education
York University
BA, Psychology
1982 - 1987
None

# Mark Falzon **Restaurant Business Owner-Now Open!-Famiglia Ristorante-Ancaster** Canada, CA 500 connections, 2293 followers ## About Contact Information NAME: Mark Falzon CITY, STATE: Ancaster, Ontario CONTACT / SOCIAL MEDIA Email: m

marcogroup@gmail

com Telephone: (647) 542-2100 Professional Headline Experienced Operations & Strategy Leader VALUE PROPOSITION ► I am highly effective in operations management and strategic planning, with experience delivering results in leadership roles overseeing the operational and financial performance of multiple sites across various industries

► My success is driven by my ability to lead initiatives that improve productivity while meeting operating and fiscal targets

SUMMARY ► Engaging operations and strategy executive possessing a winning blend of business expertise, skill in regional operations management, and practical experience in large organizations

► Leverages a unique mix of strategic and analytical expertise, consistently exceeding performance goals by aligning the effort of strong teams with organizational objectives

LEADERSHIP HIGHLIGHTS ★ With Great Clips, expanded the company’s presence in Ontario, Canada, recruiting and mentoring new franchise owners with responsibility for over 70 store locations

★ Successfully partnered with the Canadian Real Estate Manager to establish an Ontario territory plan, assessing existing locations and mapping an expansion strategy

★ In a prior role, directed the expansion of the Uncle Bob’s Country Buffet brand to Ontario, leading end-to-end project management for two 10,000 square foot restaurant locations in two years

## Experience ### Owner/President [Famiglia Ristorante](N/A) Aug 2022 - Present Ancaster, Ontario, Canada ### Franchise Business Coach [THE TEN SPOT beauty bar](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/the-ten-spot-inc-) May 2021 - Jun 2022 Ontario, Canada Mark was responsible for overseeing all operational components of the franchised locations,including financial performance, protocol compliance and overall business success. Mark buildsstrong relationships with franchise partners to drive results through influence resulting inmaximizing sales and enhancing the best possible guest experience. ### Chief Executive Officer [Marco Group Inc Consulting](N/A) Nov 2019 - May 2021 Ontario, Canada ★ Advises clients in the Hospitality, Building Construction, Food & Beverage, and Architecture industries to recommend technical solutions and improvements in processes.★ Leads assessments of client business operations and finances, , including costs, budgets, and P&L, identifying opportunities for improvement and risk management.★ Works with Hospitality industry clients to expand through franchising, developing legal documentation, franchise agreements, disclosures documents, and employee handbooks.★ Retained by a Building Construction client to achieve compliance with requirements by the Workplace Safety & Insurance Board, developing safety procedures.★ Collaborated with an Architecture firm to develop staffing requirements and estimates to aid in workforce planning for projects.☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲ABOUT MARCO GROUP INC. CONSULTINGMarco Group Inc. Consulting works with companies in the Food & Beverage industry to develop strong business strategies, manage projects, improve safety, and achieve growth. ### Ontario Operations Manager [Great Clips Inc.](https://www.linkedin.com/company/greatclips) Jul 2017 - Nov 2019 Ontario ★ Responsible for growing the brand’s presence in Canada, overseeing the expansion of franchise operations in Ontario. Worked with the Canadian Real Estate Manager to establish an Ontario territory plan, assessing existing locations and mapping an expansion strategy.★ Advised franchise owners of over 70 stores on strategies to maximize profitability and expand. Implemented new procedures and training to improve the customer experience and minimize wait times.★ Consistently met goals for new franchise recruitment, sales, marketing, budget management, personnel management, and inventory.★ Successful in increase consumer adoption of the mobile and digital app for booking appointments from 26% to 43.4%.★ Partnered with Healthcare and Beauty brands to drive revenue from the retail sales of products throughout Ontario locations.☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲☲ABOUT GREAT CLIPSGreat Clips, Inc. operates a chain of salons and is a leader in the haircutting industry. The company provides hair care products such as conditioners, detanglers, gels, hair sprays, foams, shampoos, shines, straightening products, texturizers, thermal protectants, and volumizers. Great Clips offers personal care and styling products for men, women, and children. ### Executive Director Of Operations [Uncle Bob's Franchise Corporation/Mandarin Franchise Group](N/A) Jan 2015 - Jul 2017 Brampton, Ontario. ★ Debuted the Uncle Bob’s Country Buffet brand in Ontario, leading projects to build and open two 10,000 square foot restaurants in two years. Dan Holman
Business Owner | Speaker | Implementer | Retail Mentor | Consultant I Trainer
St Albert, Alberta, Canada
500 connections, 1600 followers


About
Dan has spent more than 30 years in the retail and service industries. Specializing in marketing & business development, inventory planning, operations and customer driven sales management. He is an award-winning business coach with a proven understanding of what it takes to be successful as an entrepreneur. Dan spent 16 years in senior management and ownership roles with multi-store retailers before joining Canadian Retail Solutions as their CEO, Director of Retail Planning. Dan works directly with clients’ coast to coast representing hundreds of retail categories. He is the founder of The Wealthy Retailer™ which began as an educational series delivering a successive in-depth look at key areas for growing and nurturing retail stores to maximize their profit potential.

About
Ferociously committed to helping entrepreneurs around the world. Believer that the world's toughest challenges can be only solved by entrepreneurs. Committed especially to helping the founders who didn’t go to the right schools or grow up in the right families or look like everyone else. Hustle should always matter more than pedigree. Co-founded and led Clearco (formerly Clearbanc) to become the world’s largest e-commerce investor. We’ve invested in over $3.2B in over 7,000 different companies across 10 countries. We’ve backed 25x more women than the VC industry average and backed founders in all 50 states in America by using AI to make our investment decisions and not humans. We pioneered the revenue share capital structure for ad spend and inventory that has been copied (to the enormous benefit of founders!) around the world. We were Softbank’s first Canadian investment at a near $2B valuation launching Clearco into unicorn status. Investor on CBC’s Dragons’ Den (Canada’s Shark Tank) for over 6 seasons with dozens of angel investments including Endy (acquired by Sleep Country for $89M), TruLocal (acquired by Emerge for $17M), RVezy, Thras.io, Haus, Cart.com, Sheetex, Signos, Mastermind, Inkbox, TruFan, Lillia, Lucky Iron Fish, Accompany.io, Swyft and Tokens.com. Voted Angel Investor of the Year in Canada. Committed to becoming a better leader myself. I’m constantly pushing myself out of my comfort zone and scared all the time. I’ve learned it’s never easy to lead. Loves: Cabernet, Alicia Keys, the color purple, water sports, sailing, booking airline tickets 2 hours before takeoff.

results.title: Why Canadian design matters: a founder's perspective
results.content: If we want a future where brands like Origyn can thrive, we need more retailers who treat Canadian design as cultural infrastructure, not just product. Thats why local retailers like La Maison Simons matter. Theyre one of the few nationally recognized retail companies: - still family-owned - still headquartered in Canada - still investing in Canadian design and independent makers At Origyn, were creating ethically sourced, small-batch handbags that dont fit easily into mass retail. We need retail partners who understand the value of slow production, regional materials, and long-term thinking. As Canadian brands try to build a different kind of futureSimons is a rare example of retail taking the long view.
results.raw_content:
# Why Canadian design matters: a founder's perspective

This title was summarized by AI from the post below.

[Laurie Baker, PhD](https://ca.linkedin.com/in/lauriembaker?trk=public_post_feed-actor-name)

Founder of Origyn - Plant-based leather accessories & Executive Director - Treefrog Accelerator

* [Report this post](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fposts%2Flauriembaker_canadaday-origyn-simons-activity-7345812599034343424-uUS5&trk=public_post_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=POST&_f=guest-reporting)

As a founder building a Canadian brand from the ground up, I think a lot about the systems that make or break independent businesses. Canadian fashion isnt just about what we makeits about who makes space for it. The reality is: if youre producing ethically, using innovative, next-gen materials, and refusing to cut corners, the margins are challenging. You need retail partners who get it. Who believe in more than volume. Who are willing to take risks on ideas that dont always look scalable at first glance. I respect what [La Maison Simons](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/maisonsimons?trk=public_post-text) has built. Theyve managed to grow without abandoning the ecosystem they came from. Theyve supported Canadian design in real, tangible waysand thats rare. If we want a future where brands like [Origyn](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/origyn-apparel?trk=public_post-text) can thrive, we need more retailers who treat Canadian design as cultural infrastructure, not just product. Grateful to everyone building that future. [#CanadaDay](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fcanadaday&trk=public_post-text) [#Origyn](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Forigyn&trk=public_post-text) [#Simons](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fsimons&trk=public_post-text) [#SupportLocalBusiness](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fsupportlocalbusiness&trk=public_post-text) [#EthicalFashion](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fethicalfashion&trk=public_post-text) [#RetailWithPurpose](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fretailwithpurpose&trk=public_post-text) [#WomenInBusiness](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fwomeninbusiness&trk=public_post-text)

[Origyn](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/origyn-apparel?trk=public_post_reshare_feed-actor-name)

38 followers

Canada Day is a good time to talk about some of the infrastructure that actually supports Canadian business. If you're building a values-driven brand in Canadaespecially in fashionyou know the odds are long. Production is expensive. Supply chains are fragile. And most major retail channels are either closing (Hudsons Bay) or owned elsewhere. Thats why local retailers like [La Maison Simons](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/maisonsimons?trk=public_post_reshare-text) matter. Theyre one of the few nationally recognized retail companies: - still family-owned - still headquartered in Canada - still investing in Canadian design and independent makers At Origyn, were creating ethically sourced, small-batch handbags that dont fit easily into mass retail. What we need isnt just shelf spacewe need alignment. We need retail partners who understand the value of slow production, regional materials, and long-term thinking. [La Maison Simons](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/maisonsimons?trk=public_post_reshare-text) has shown its possible to scale without losing sight of local. As Canadian brands try to build a different kind of futureSimons is a rare example of retail taking the long view. [#CanadaDay](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fcanadaday&trk=public_post_reshare-text) [#CanadianRetail](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fcanadianretail&trk=public_post_reshare-text) [#Origyn](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Forigyn&trk=public_post_reshare-text) [#Simons](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fsimons&trk=public_post_reshare-text) [#SupportLocal](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Ffeed%2Fhashtag%2Fsupportlocal&trk=public_post_reshare-text)

results.title: Sujeevan Moorthy - President of Chiang Mai | Restaurant ...
results.content:
Sujeevan Moorthy
President of Chiang Mai | Restaurant Success Mentor | A Guide from Family Kitchens to Restaurant Royalty
Toronto, Ontario, Canada
177 connections, 194 followers


About
I took my first steps in the restaurant business at my father's restaurant and progressed through various roles at renowned chains like Pickle Barrel and Milestones. This experience has been the foundation for creating Chiang Mai, which started as a single location in Toronto and has since grown into a beloved chain. Today, my focus is on empowering small, family-run restaurants and industry managers. I specialize in menu development, financial management, and enhancing the customer experience, all to drive restaurant success. I mentor aspiring restaurateurs, managers, and chefs, helping them navigate the challenges of the restaurant business while celebrating their achievements. My ultimate goal is to enable others to realize their culinary ambitions and succeed in a competitive industry. If you're ready to take your restaurant to the next level, let's connect and begin crafting your success story!


Experience
Founder and President
[Chiang Mai Thai Kitchen and Bar](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/chiangmaito)  
Jan 2019 - Present
Toronto, Ontario, Canada
As the founder and visionary behind Chiang Mai, I transformed a single Toronto restaurant into a thriving chain known for its unique Thai-fusion cuisine. My role involves strategic oversight of culinary innovation, business growth, and brand development. I've successfully steered the chain through market expansions, menu diversification, and operational efficiencies, establishing Chiang Mai as a landmark in the culinary landscape.


Education
Centennial College
Accounting
2008 - 2012
None

results.title: Michael Noble - Chef/Proprietor at The Nash Restaurant & ...
results.content:
Michael Noble
Chef/Proprietor at The Nash Restaurant & Off Cut Bar
Calgary, Alberta, Canada
500 connections, 894 followers


About
I've worked in all aspects of the culinary profession, from small restaurants to large chains, large and small hotels and also have done a number of consulting jobs either opening new restaurant concepts or overhauling existing ones. My strengths aside from a depth of culinary experience are with people, giving them the knowlege and tools to succeed. I've made a legacy in my career of all the great people who have worked with me and who have gone on to create amazing success for themselves in their own careers. Specialties: NOtaBLE ~ The Restaurant is a full service restaurant which opened in August of 2010. The style of cuisine is "Gourmet Comfort", everything is made in our open kitchen which features a large wood and charcoal burning rotisserie on which you will find succulent aromatic rubbed chickens and a roast feature on every day.


Experience
Chef/Proprietor
[The Nash Restaurant & Off Cut Bar](N/A)  
Nov 2014 - Present
Calgary, Alberta, Canada
My legacy project, combining everything that I've learned in 35+ years in the restaurant industry.This beauty is housed in the former National Hotel, which was opened in July of 1907. The former hotel sat empty for a number of years until I joined forces with interior designer Sarah Ward of Sarah Ward Interiors to create this beautiful room which honours the many decades of history in the neighbourhood of Inglewood. The restaurant consists of the light, airy main dining room which faces into the open kitchen and rotisserie bar and which does a modern take on comforting and satisfying dishes, served in a crisp yet friendly way. The restaurant space includes Off Cut Bar - the somewhat badass, sexy, sultry and yet extremely welcoming area which serves contemporary and classic cocktails along with craft beers, great wines and a menu featuring all secondary cuts of meat, poultry and seafood.One hundred and fifty seats in all, including interesting seating areas and tables made from recovered Canadian prairie barn wood and featuring two community tables situated directly beside the kitchen.


Education
Vancouver Community College
CCFCC Red Seal, Culinary
1979 - 1980
None

results.title: The Top 10 Laws Governing Small Business Owners in ...
results.content: # The Top 10 Laws Governing Small Business Owners in Canada This article highlights the top 10 laws every small business owner in Canada should be aware of to navigate the regulatory landscape effectively. By staying informed about these top 10 laws, you can build a strong legal foundation for your business, avoid costly mistakes, and focus on growth. Business Registration and Licensing Laws The Canada Occupational Health and Safety Regulations apply to federally regulated businesses, while provincial guidelines govern most other businesses. Businesses must comply with Canada’s Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA), which governs the collection, use, and disclosure of personal information. Businesses selling goods or services to consumers must comply with federal and provincial consumer protection laws.
results.raw_content:
[Skip to main content](#main-content)






# The Top 10 Laws Governing Small Business Owners in Canada

[Paul Kidston MBA, ICD.D](https://ca.linkedin.com/in/paulkidston)

### Paul Kidston MBA, ICD.D

#### 🇨🇦 🇺🇦Senior Business & Government Advisor | Strategic Growth & Financial Management | Operational Efficiency | Sales & Market Expansion

[+ Follow](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=%2Fpulse%2Ftop-10-laws-governing-small-business-owners-canada-paul-bncie&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_publisher-author-card)

Starting and running a small business in Canada is an exciting journey, but it comes with a host of legal obligations. Understanding these laws is crucial for compliance and long-term success. This article highlights the top 10 laws every small business owner in Canada should be aware of to navigate the regulatory landscape effectively.

### Executive Summary

Running a small business in Canada is as rewarding as it is complex. By staying informed about these top 10 laws, you can build a strong legal foundation for your business, avoid costly mistakes, and focus on growth. Regularly consult with legal professionals and keep abreast of changes in legislation to ensure compliance in all aspects of your business operations



---



### 1. Business Registration and Licensing Laws

Every small business in Canada must be registered with the appropriate authorities. The type of registration—sole proprietorship, partnership, or incorporation—depends on the structure of your business. Each province has its own process, such as ServiceOntario for Ontario-based businesses or Service Alberta for Alberta. Additionally, some businesses require specific licenses or permits to operate, depending on the industry and location.



---



### 2. Taxation Laws

Tax compliance is a cornerstone of running a business in Canada. Small business owners must register for a business number (BN) through the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA). Depending on your revenue, you may also need to collect and remit Goods and Services Tax (GST) or Harmonized Sales Tax (HST). Familiarize yourself with income tax obligations, payroll taxes, and potential tax credits or deductions for small businesses.



---



### 3. Employment Laws

If you employ staff, understanding Canadian employment laws is non-negotiable. These laws cover minimum wage, overtime pay, vacation entitlement, statutory holidays, and termination procedures. Employment laws vary by province, so ensure you’re compliant with local regulations. For instance, Ontario’s Employment Standards Act (ESA) differs from British Columbia’s Employment Standards Act.



---



### 4. Health and Safety Regulations

All businesses must adhere to occupational health and safety regulations to ensure a safe working environment. The Canada Occupational Health and Safety Regulations apply to federally regulated businesses, while provincial guidelines govern most other businesses. Failing to meet these standards can lead to penalties and jeopardize employee well-being.



---



### 5. Privacy and Data Protection Laws

In today’s digital economy, protecting customer and employee data is paramount. Businesses must comply with Canada’s Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA), which governs the collection, use, and disclosure of personal information. If you operate within Quebec, you must also adhere to the newly amended Act Respecting the Protection of Personal Information in the Private Sector.



---



### 6. Consumer Protection Laws

Businesses selling goods or services to consumers must comply with federal and provincial consumer protection laws. These laws ensure that products are safe, advertising is truthful, and contracts are fair. For instance, the Competition Act prohibits deceptive marketing practices, while the Canadian Consumer Product Safety Act (CCPSA) enforces product safety standards.



---



### 7. Intellectual Property Laws

Protecting intellectual property (IP) is vital for small businesses that create unique products, services, or brands. The Canadian Intellectual Property Office (CIPO) oversees trademarks, copyrights, and patents. Registering your IP ensures exclusive rights and safeguards your business from infringement.



---



### 8. Environmental Laws

Businesses operating in industries with environmental impacts, such as manufacturing or construction, must comply with federal, provincial, and municipal environmental regulations. These laws address waste management, emissions, and conservation practices. For example, the Canadian Environmental Protection Act (CEPA) regulates substances that can harm the environment or human health.



---



### 9. Contracts and Commercial Law

Contracts are the backbone of business relationships, whether with clients, suppliers, or employees. Understanding contract law is crucial to drafting enforceable agreements. The Sale of Goods Act, applicable in most provinces, governs transactions involving the sale of goods. For more complex business arrangements, seeking legal counsel is advisable.



---



### 10. Bankruptcy and Insolvency Laws

While no entrepreneur starts a business expecting financial distress, understanding bankruptcy laws can be critical in challenging times. The Bankruptcy and Insolvency Act (BIA) provides a legal framework for restructuring or winding up a business. This law aims to balance the interests of creditors and debtors while offering relief for businesses seeking a fresh start.



---



###

# Can I Register a Business in Canada as a Non-Resident?

* [Report this article](/uas/login?session_redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linkedin.com%2Fpulse%2Fcan-i-register-business-canada-non-resident-ccxoc&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_ellipsis-menu-semaphore-sign-in-redirect&guestReportContentType=PONCHO_ARTICLE&_f=guest-reporting)

[LCS - Logistics and Customs Services Inc.](https://ca.linkedin.com/company/logistics-and-customs-services) 

### LCS - Logistics and Customs Services Inc.

#### Simplifying Customs: Seamless Shipping, Customized Solutions. Now in Canada and North America.

Published May 23, 2025

[+ Follow](https://www.linkedin.com/signup/cold-join?session_redirect=%2Fpulse%2Fcan-i-register-business-canada-non-resident-ccxoc&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_publisher-author-card)

Canada’s welcoming environment for entrepreneurs and businesses extends beyond its borders. If you’re a non-resident considering starting a business here, you’ll be pleased to know that it is indeed possible. However, the process involves navigating specific regulations and understanding the tax implications, particularly concerning the Goods and Services Tax (GST) and Harmonized Sales Tax (HST).

### Understanding Non-Resident Business Registration

Before diving into the steps, it’s important to grasp what being a non-resident means in Canada. Basically, a non-resident can be a person or an entity like a corporation, partnership, or other organization that doesn’t live or have an established presence in Canada. This could include people who live abroad, or businesses set up in other countries. Understanding this concept helps to better navigate the rules and regulations that apply to non-residents in Canada.

### Determining Residency Status

According to the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA), residency status is determined by several factors:

* Individuals: Considerations include ties to Canada (such as a home or family), length of stay abroad, and regularity of visits.

* Corporations: A corporation is considered a resident if it is incorporated in Canada or if its central management and control are exercised within the country.

### Carrying on Business in Canada

Non-residents must determine if they are “carrying on business” in Canada, which could obligate GST/HST registration. This involves assessing activities such as the location of business agents, place of delivery and payment, and where contracts are made.

### Steps to Register a Business in Canada as a Non-Resident

Step 1: Decide on a Business Structure

Decide if your business will operate as a sole proprietorship, partnership, or corporation. Each structure has different legal implications and tax obligations.

Step 2: Choose a Business Name

Ensure the business name is unique and registers it in the province or territory where your business will operate. It’s advisable to conduct a name search through the NUANS database to avoid duplication.

Step 3: Determine GST/HST Obligations

Review the CRA’s [guidelines](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Ecanada%2Eca%2Fen%2Frevenue-agency%2Fservices%2Fforms-publications%2Fpublications%2Frc4027%2Fdoing-business-canada-gst-hst-information-non-residents%2Ehtml&urlhash=BVPN&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block) on GST/HST to understand if you need to register. Non-residents providing taxable supplies in Canada may need to collect and remit GST/HST.

Step 4: Obtain a Business Number

Apply for a Business Number (BN) through the CRA. This unique identifier is used to manage GST/HST accounts, payroll, and other tax matters.

Step 5: Secure Necessary Permits and Licenses

Depending on your industry, you may require specific permits or licenses to operate legally in Canada. It’s crucial to check both federal and provincial requirements.

Step 6: Set Up a Bank Account

While not mandatory, having a Canadian bank account can facilitate smoother financial transactions and tax payments.

### Benefits of Registering a Business in Canada as a Non-Resident

* Access to North American Markets: Canada’s strategic trade agreements offer businesses expanded market access.

* Stable Economy: Canada’s robust economy provides a stable environment for business growth.

* Innovation Ecosystem: Benefit from Canada’s thriving tech and innovation sectors, particularly if entering fields like AI or fintech.

### Challenges and Considerations

* Tax Compliance: Navigating GST/HST and other tax obligations can be complex. Engaging a Canadian tax advisor is beneficial.

* Market Penetration: Understanding the Canadian consumer market and establishing a local presence may require additional resources.

### Conclusion

Registering a business in Canada as a non-resident opens numerous opportunities but requires careful planning and compliance with local regulations. Whether you’re testing the waters with a small enterprise or venturing into large-scale operations, Canada’s business-friendly climate can be a significant advantage.

Are you ready to get started? Learn more about how to register your business and stay compliant by visiting the [CBSA Website](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww%2Ecbsa-asfc%2Egc%2Eca%2F&urlhash=TAsS&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block). Get expert advice to make your entry into the Canadian market smooth and hassle-free. For tailored guidance and support, reach out to us. [Contact us](https://www.linkedin.com/redir/redirect?url=https%3A%2F%2Flcslogistics%2Ecom%2Fcontact-us-lcs-custom-broker%2F&urlhash=PhPP&trk=article-ssr-frontend-pulse_little-text-block) today and let our experts help you every step of the way. Whether you have questions or need assistance, we’re here to make the process easier for you.

**Ready to make your next big professional move? Join us on our journey to achieve our big dream of building the most loved restaurant brands in the world.** Restaurant Brands International Inc. is one of the world's largest quick service restaurant companies with nearly $45 billion in annual system-wide sales and over 32,000 restaurants in more than 120 countries and territories.RBI owns four of the world's most prominent and iconic quick service restaurant brands – TIM HORTONS®, BURGER KING®, POPEYES®, and FIREHOUSE SUBS®. These independently operated brands have been serving their respective guests, franchisees and communities for decades. Through its Restaurant Brands for Good framework, RBI is improving sustainable outcomes related to its food, the planet, and people and communities.RBI is committed to growing the TIM HORTONS®, BURGER KING®, POPEYES® and FIREHOUSE SUBS® brands by leveraging their respective core values, employee and franchisee relationships, and long track records of community support. Each brand benefits from the global scale and shared best practices that come from ownership by Restaurant Brands International Inc.**Position Overview**Reporting to the Sr. Manager, TH CPG Finance, the Manager, TH Finance will be responsible for managing all financial routines including month-end closing and reporting processes, in addition to ad hoc reporting, analyses, and financial modeling. The ideal candidate will have a finance or accounting background and the ability to interpret key financial information. The candidate should be a hands-on team player with excellent interpersonal, communication and leadership skills. They must have the ability to understand finance & accounting concepts and be able to convey information in a clear and concise manner to a variety of audiences.**Responsibilities**

* Lead the monthly closing process for Tim Hortons CPG including commentary and insights on the results
* Lead the monthly forecast process, working with business partners to forecast and drive results
* Lead the annual budget process in collaboration with the CPG business team
* Perform monthly analysis of trade spend, identifying effectiveness of promotional activity and areas for optimization
* Prepare retailer and product level financial reports, highlighting key findings and actionable insights
* Work with Corporate Accounting and Shared Services areas to ensure that results are consistent with U.S. GAAP
* Assist with various ad hoc projects and financial modeling to support business decisions as needed

**Requirements**

* 4+ years of finance or accounting experience
* High degree of comfort with Microsoft Office applications and ERP systems; SAP, OneStream and IBM Planning Analytics experience considered an asset
* Strong organizational skills required to meet tight reporting deadlines
* Excellent interpersonal and communication skills
* Undergraduate degree in finance or accounting an asset

Benefits at all of our global offices are focused on physical, mental and financial wellness. We offer unique and progressive benefits, including a comprehensive global paid parental leave program that supports employees as they expand their families, free telemedicine and mental wellness support.Restaurant Brands International and all of its affiliated companies (collectively, RBI) are equal opportunity and affirmative action employers that do not discriminate on the basis of race, national origin, religion, age, color, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, disability, or veteran status, or any other characteristic protected by local, state, provincial or federal laws, rules, or regulations. RBI's policy applies to all terms and conditions of employment. Accommodation is available for applicants with disabilities upon request.
